structured_info.title_cn: 释放联网与自动驾驶车辆的潜力：混合交通高效管理的专用链路策略
structured_info.title_en: Unleashing the Power of Connected and Automated Vehicles: A Dedicated Link Strategy for Efficient Management of Mixed Traffic
structured_info.abstract: The proper management of mixed traffic is crucial for unleashing the benefits of connected and automated vehicles (CAVs). Generally, the benefits of CAVs can be categorized into one-dimensional benefits in car-following performance and two-dimensional benefits in efficiently addressing right-of-way conflicts. Currently, the most effective approach to achieve this is by establishing a dedicated right-of-way for CAVs. However, existing strategies are limited to dedicated lane strategy, which can only unleash the one-dimensional benefits of CAVs while the two-dimensional benefits remain untapped. Therefore, this paper proposes a novel management approach for mixed traffic called the dedicated link strategy. The dedicated link refers to the road link that only allows CAVs to use. This strategy can unleash both the one-dimensional and two-dimensional benefits of CAVs via: (i) dedicated link deployment at the road network level and (ii) a novel intersection management approach. Specifically, at the macroscopic road network level, we introduce a bi-level dedicated link deployment model and design an artificial bee colony based algorithm to solve the optimal dedicated link deployment. At the microscopic intersection level, we develop a novel intersection management approach that integrates traditional traffic signal strategy with the emerging signal-free cooperative driving method, thereby boosting the efficiency of intersections. The macroscopic and microscopic methods will complement each other to achieve efficient management of network-wide mixed traffic systems. Finally, we verify the performance of the dedicated link strategy through comprehensive experiments.
structured_info.methodology: The paper proposes a bi-level optimization model for dedicated link deployment at the macroscopic level and an artificial bee colony algorithm for solving the NP-hard problem. At the microscopic level, it introduces a novel intersection management approach integrating traffic signal control with signal-free cooperative driving methods.
structured_info.conclusion: The dedicated link strategy significantly enhances the efficiency of mixed traffic systems by unleashing both one-dimensional and two-dimensional benefits of CAVs. It improves travel efficiency for CAVs while minimizing impact on HDVs, and the proposed algorithms effectively solve the deployment and management challenges.
structured_info.venue: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems

analysis.Overview: The paper introduces a dedicated link strategy for managing mixed traffic systems, focusing on maximizing the benefits of connected and automated vehicles (CAVs) through dedicated infrastructure and advanced intersection management.
Background_and_Motivation: The transition to fully autonomous driving involves a prolonged period of mixed traffic with both CAVs and human-driven vehicles (HDVs).
Current strategies like dedicated lanes only partially utilize CAV benefits, missing opportunities in right-of-way conflict resolution.
The paper argues for a comprehensive approach to leverage CAV capabilities fully, addressing both car-following efficiency and intersection management.
The research bridges gaps in existing traffic management by proposing a unified strategy for mixed traffic environments.
Contributions span transportation engineering, autonomous systems, and traffic optimization.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Dedicated Link Strategy: Road links exclusively for CAVs to separate traffic flows and enable efficient management.
Bi-level Optimization Model: Combines network-level deployment with traffic assignment for optimal resource use.
Assumes CAVs can communicate and coordinate, and that dedicated infrastructure can be dynamically allocated.
The paper contributes a novel management paradigm and algorithmic solutions to mixed traffic challenges.
Methodology: Uses a bi-level model for dedicated link deployment and an artificial bee colony algorithm for optimization.
Novelty lies in integrating macroscopic network planning with microscopic intersection control.
Data includes traffic flow models and simulation-based validation, ensuring representativeness of urban traffic scenarios.
Experimental design includes comprehensive simulations to validate performance across different traffic densities.
Follows a systems optimization paradigm, focusing on network-wide efficiency.
Results: The dedicated link strategy improves traffic flow efficiency, particularly at medium to high densities.
Results show significant reductions in travel time for CAVs with minimal impact on HDVs.
The artificial bee colony algorithm efficiently finds near-optimal deployment schemes.
Argumentation_and_Logic: The paper systematically presents the problem, solution framework, and validation.
Key steps include problem formulation, algorithmic design, and experimental verification.
Strengths include comprehensive simulation results; potential weaknesses may include scalability in very large networks.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Innovations include the dedicated link concept and integrated intersection management.
Limitations include assumptions about CAV penetration rates and communication reliability.
Theoretical focus may require adaptation for real-world implementation challenges.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Positions the work within ongoing discourse on CAV integration and traffic management.
Uses technical terminology and cites extensively to build on prior research.
Citations establish credibility and contextualize contributions within the field.
Conclusions_and_Implications: The dedicated link strategy effectively manages mixed traffic, enhancing CAV benefits while accommodating HDVs.
Future work could explore dynamic deployment and real-time adaptation strategies.
